conclusion: A plate with mass M is moving on a horizontal surface. At time t=0, a block with mass m is placed on the plate with zero initial velocity. The block does not leave the plate during motion. M=2m, and neither the block and the plate nor the plate and the surface are smooth.
The acceleration due to gravity is g=10 m/s².
The relationship between the velocity of the block and time from t=0 is shown in Figure B.
We need to analyze the motion of the block and the plate separately and use the relationship between their velocities and frictional forces.
The block is initially at rest and placed on the moving plate. The plate has mass M=2m and the block has mass m.
The block and the plate will have different accelerations due to frictional forces.
Let the acceleration of the block be a_2 and the acceleration of the plate be a_1.

premise: For the block, the only force acting on it is the frictional force μ_1 mg.
conclusion: μ_1 mg = ma_2 implies a_2 = μ_1 g

premise: For the plate, the forces acting on it are the frictional force μ_1 mg and the frictional force μ_2 (M + m)g.
conclusion: μ_1 mg - μ_2 (2m + m)g = 2ma_1 implies a_1 = (μ_1 g - 3μ_2 g)/2
The block and the plate will reach the same velocity when the block catches up with the plate.
The velocity of the block as a function of time is given by the area under the velocity-time graph in Figure B.
Assume the form of the velocity-time graph is linear and the velocity of the block as a function of time is v_b(t) = μ_1 gt.
The velocity of the plate as a function of time is v_p(t) = v_0 + a_1 t, where v_0 is the initial velocity of the plate.
The initial velocity of the plate is not given, and we are only interested in the relative motion.

premise: The relative velocity is v_b - v_p = μ_1 gt - (v_0 + a_1 t).
conclusion: Since the block and the plate reach the same velocity, μ_1 gt = v_0 + a_1 t.
